sections.text: Interactive notebooks can make bioinformatics data analyses more transparent, accessible and reusable. However, creating notebooks requires computer programming expertise. Here we introduce BioJupies, a web server that enables automated creation, storage, and deployment of Jupyter Notebooks containing RNA-seq data analyses. Through an intuitive interface, novice users can rapidly generate tailored reports to analyze and visualize their own raw sequencing files, their gene expression tables, or fetch data from >5,500 published studies containing >250,000 preprocessed RNA-seq samples. Generated notebooks have executable code of the entire pipeline, rich narrative text, interactive data visualizations, and differential expression and enrichment analyses. The notebooks are permanently stored in the cloud and made available online through a persistent URL. The notebooks are downloadable, customizable, and can run within a Docker container. By providing an intuitive user interface for notebook generation for RNA-seq data analysis, starting from the raw reads, all the way to a complete interactive and reproducible report, BioJupies is a useful resource for experimental and computational biologists. BioJupies is freely available as a web-based application from: http://biojupies.cloud and as a Chrome extension from the Chrome Web Store.

sections.title: Overview
sections.text:
BioJupies allows users to generate customized analysis notebooks from RNA-seq data through an intuitive interface, with no knowledge of coding required.
Generating a notebook requires three steps:
  1. Select the data you wish to analyze. You can upload your own RNA-seq data - either as raw FASTQ files or as tables containing gene counts - or search over 8,000 publicly available datasets published in the Gene Expression Omnibus and processed by ARCHS4.
  2. Add Data Analysis Plugins. After selecting the data, you can choose from over 10 data visualization and analysis plugins which will analyze the RNA-seq dataset and embed interactive results in the resulting notebook.
  3. Generate your notebook. Once you have selected the tools, you can generate the notebook directly from the BioJupies website. The notebook will be returned to you through a permanent, public URL.
To start generating you notebook, visit https://amp.pharm.mssm.edu/biojupies/analyze.

sections.title: Uploading your Data
sections.text:
BioJupies allows you to generate customized Jupyter Notebooks by uploading your RNA-seq from https://amp.pharm.mssm.edu/biojupies/upload.Data can be uploaded in two formats:
  1. FASTQ Files. You can upload raw sequencing data in the .fastq.gz format directly to BioJupies. The web server will align your reads to the selected reference genome and generate a notebook from the estimated gene counts. For more information about uploading FASTQ files, click here.
  2. Gene Count Tables. If you already performed sequence alignment, you can upload text files containing raw gene counts. Uploaded files must have gene symbols on rows and samples on columns. For more information about uploading gene counts, click here.
Once you have uploaded your data, proceed to Adding Analysis Plugins.

sections.title: Searching Published Data
sections.text:
In addition to uploading your data, BioJupies users can also analyze over 8,000 publicly available datasets published in the Gene Expression Omnibus and processed by ARCHS4 from https://amp.pharm.mssm.edu/biojupies/analyze/search.Users can filter datasets by using text-based search, filter by organism, or by number of RNA-seq samples contained in the dataset. By clicking on More Info you can access a detailed description of the dataset and a link to its landing page on the Gene Expression Omnibus.
Once you have selected a dataset, click Analyze and proceed to Adding Analysis Plugins.

sections.title: Adding Analysis Plugins
sections.text: Once you have selected a dataset you wish to analyze, you can add one or more RNA-seq analysis plugins to analyze your data and embed interactive results and plots in your notebook. You can toggle plugins by clicking on the Add or Remove buttons displayed on the right of each card. You can access additional information about each plugin by clicking on the More Info button. Once you have selected the desired plugins, click Continue. If you only selected plugins in the Exploratory Data Analysis category, proceed to Customizing Parameters; otherwise proceed to Selecting Groups.

sections.title: Selecting Groups
sections.text:
If you select one or more plugins in the Differential Expression, Enrichment Analysis or Small Molecule Query categories, you are required to specify two groups of samples to compare in order to generate a gene expression signature. To achieve this, you can select the samples you wish to assign to each group using the interface shown below.To assign samples to the desired group, you can use the dropdown menu displayed on the left of each sample in the table. Optionally, you can name the groups of samples using the text boxes provided. The Predict Groups feature will automatically predict the samples belonging to each group by searching the provided name in the corresponding sample metadata. This feature can be turned off by using the provided switch.
Once you have selected the desired groups, click Continue and proceed to Customizing Parameters.

sections.title: Customizing Parameters
sections.text:
After the desired dataset and plugins have been selected, your notebook is ready to be generated. In the final step, you can customize your notebook by changing its title, adding biological tags, or modifying optional parameters for each of the selected plugins.To tag your notebook, you can select tens of thousands of biological terms coming from multiple databases and ontologies. You can specify whether the analyzed samples are affected by a specific disease, small molecule treatment or gene perturbation.You can additionally modify parameters for each of the selected tools, such as the normalization technique before displaying the heatmap and the number of genes to display.
Once you have selected the desired settings, click on Generate Notebook and proceed to the next step.

sections.title: Generating the Notebook
sections.text: Once you have selected the desired settings, you can request a notebook by clicking on Generate Notebook. This process can take between 10 seconds to 3 minutes, depending on the size of the RNA-seq dataset and the selected plugins. Once the notebook is completed, a link will be displayed on the website.Your notebook is accessible from a permanent, public URL, displayed using nbviewer.

sections.title: Accessing the Notebook
sections.text: Once completed, you can access the notebook at the permanent notebook URL.

With BioJupies you can automatically generate a Jupyter Notebook by uploading your own RNA-seq data at https://amp.pharm.mssm.edu/biojupies/upload.Data can be uploaded in two formats:
  1. FASTQ Files. You can upload raw sequencing data in the .fastq.gz format directly to BioJupies. The web server will align your reads to the selected reference genome and generate a notebook from the estimated gene counts. For more information about uploading FASTQ files, click here.
  2. Gene Count Tables. If you already performed sequence alignment, you can upload text files containing raw gene counts. Uploaded files must have gene symbols on rows and samples on columns. For more information about uploading gene counts, click here.

sections.title: Uploading Gene Counts
sections.text:
If you have a matrix of gene-level counts, you can upload it using the expression table file upload page, available at https://amp.pharm.mssm.edu/biojupies/upload/table.In order to successfully upload a table, your file should follow the following format:
  • Have gene symbols on the rows. While other gene identifiers are supported (e.g. Ensembl IDs, Entrez IDs), gene symbols will provide the best results for downstream enrichment analysis and small molecule queries.
  • Have sample names on the columns.
  • Have raw gene expression counts as values.

sections.title: 5. Using the Chrome Extension
sections.text: Instructions on installing and using the BioJupies Google Chrome extension. For more information see the Chrome Extension section.

sections.title: 6. Reusing Notebooks
sections.text: Overview of how users can download, execute and customize BioJupies Notebooks on their local computer (Mac OS shown). For more information see the Reusing Notebooks section.
BioJupies is currently available as a pre-print on bioRxiv: https://www.biorxiv.org/content/early/2018/06/20/352476

Source code for BioJupies is available at https://github.com/MaayanLab/biojupies, under the Apache License 2.0. Provided gene expression files are available under the Creative Commons Attribution 4.0 International License.
BioJupies is free to use for non-commercial purposes. For commercial use, please contact MSIP.
